items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Rising river levels this morning may lead to flooding.
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is possible when river levels are at their highest from 9:04 AM on 29/08/2025.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Shuttle/ Cray, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads along the river. / low lying land and roads along the River Shuttle particularly in and around Bexley.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon but no further flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 9:05 AM on 30/08/2025, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen in Barnham following Friday mornings rain. In Bersted river levels are a little higher than normal but are not expected to rise much higher. Further scattered showers are expected this afternoon (29/08/2025) and Saturday but we are not expecting this to cause any flooding impacts. We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: River levels have fallen following Friday mornings rain. Scattered showers are expected this afternoon (29/08/2025) and Saturday but we are not expecting this to cause any flooding impacts. items.description: River Pol and Langreek Stream at Polperro
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Pol and Langreek Stream has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding is expected on Friday, however further rainfall is forecast on Saturday which may lead to further flooding.

Water levels in the Western Yar at Freshwater have now fallen.  40mm of rain fell in 3 hours up to 06:00 this morning, Friday (29/08/25). Further short showers are expected throughout the day, but river levels are not expected to rise significantly again.  We continue to monitor the forecast and will issue further advice if the situation changes.
